items.title: [a11y]: File uploader file delete button needs more context

labels.name: severity: 2
labels.description: Affects major functionality, has a workaround

items.body:
### Package @carbon/react ### Browser Chrome ### Operating System MacOS ### Package version n/a ### React version _No response_ ### Automated testing tool and ruleset inspect ### Assistive technology _No response_ ### Description As discussed at CAG, files uploaded through the File Uploader component can be removed, but the file's name is not part of the delete mechanism. When multiple files are uploaded, all the delete mechanisms ('x') are just called "Delete" (or sometimes "clear'). Since there is no confirmation prompt before deleting, it is especially important that a user who cannot see has an ability to know which file is being deleted. ![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/14298245/162801237-b974cad0-6361-4b04-ab1d-d464bf583579.png) ![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/14298245/162801973-ec1734ca-c757-4144-97f7-57162ffd11f3.png) There are several ways of resolving, this, including constructing each uploaded file as an object. However, the simplest thing to do is: 1. Consistently change the default aria-label to "delete" instead of 'clear'. 2. provide the file name through aria-describedby ![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/14298245/162802658-625108ee-ffcb-443a-8284-bdf3c6d7e1fa.png) `

button_usage_25.png

items.title: [a11y]: File uploader focus handling after file delete
items.body:
### Package

@carbon/react

### Browser

Chrome

### Operating System

MacOS

### Package version

https://react.carbondesignsystem.com/?path=/story/components-fileuploader--drag-and-drop-upload-container-example-application

### React version

_No response_

### Automated testing tool and ruleset

n/a

### Assistive technology

JAWS and keyboard

### Description

After a file is deleted from the upload list, the focus does not go anywhere. (I'll mention that the delete action does not have a confirmation, but set that aside as a design decision.) 
https://ibm.box.com/s/scxudnpq13sqvnv0jbqxamlcyp31r8kf

Prior CAG discussions on focus handling are relevant to this problem. Because the item with focus is being deleted, where should the focus go?
In prior discussions, the thought was to go the former item in the tab order. Until the delete buttons are distinguishable programmatically (#11198) it definitely makes more sense to put it on the File add button. And even once that is resolved, I think it may be a more consistent experience to always go to the File upload button regardless of which file has been delete 

We'd previously discussed the notion of a group of controls. Perhaps an interactive parent should be part of the algorithm. This same algorithm could work for table row deletions, menu item deletions and the file uploaded group of files situation.





### WCAG 2.1 Violation

https://www.w3.org/TR/UNDERSTANDING-WCAG20/navigation-mechanisms-focus-order.html

### CodeSandbox example

https://react.carbondesignsystem.com/?path=/story/components-fileuploader--drag-and-drop-upload-container-example-application

### Steps to reproduce

1. Go to https://react.carbondesignsystem.com/?path=/story/components-fileuploader--drag-and-drop-upload-container-example-application
2. Upload a few files
3. Delete a file
  - the focus will not be anywhere visually

items.title: [a11y]: File uploader status indicators need programmatic equivalent
items.body: ### Package @carbon/react ### Browser Chrome ### Operating System _No response_ ### Package version https://react.carbondesignsystem.com/?path=/story/components-fileuploader--file-uploader ### React version _No response_ ### Automated testing tool and ruleset n/a ### Assistive technology _No response_ ### Description After a user selects a file to upload from their operating system, the status of the upload is revealed through a series of images which provide no text equivalent. To meet [4.1.3 Status Messages](https://www.w3.org/WAI/WCAG21/Understanding/status-messages.html) and [1.1.1 Non-text content](https://www.w3.org/WAI/WCAG21/Understanding/non-text-content.html) - the 2 states of the file upload mechanism should be given an equivalent status message status message "uploading" --- Status message "uploaded" OR possibly "[file name] uploaded" ### Solution Provide a text equivalent, either by making the images visible to assistive technology and providing them with ALT text OR by putting them into a live region and providing text updates to that region. You could also potentially use a similiar technique to [#11198 ](https://github.com/carbon-design-system/carbon/issues/11198), using the filename as an ariadescribedby on the icon, so that the user heard 'uploaded, [filename]' ### WCAG 2.1 Violation _No response_ ### CodeSandbox example https://react.carbondesignsystem.com/?path=/story/components-fileuploader--file-uploader ### Steps to reproduce 1. Visit https://react.carbondesignsystem.com/?path=/story/components-fileuploader--file-uploader 2. use the Add file button to choose a file from your system. Choose I file close to the size limit (i.e., just under 500kb). 3. The file name will appear on the page, with an icon for 'uploading' and 'uploaded' to the right (before it becomes the 'delete') ### Code of Conduct - [X] I agree to follow this project's [Code of Conduct](https://github.com/carbon-design-system/carbon/blob/f555616971a03fd454c0f4daea184adf41fff05b/.github/CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md) - [X] I checked the [current issues](https://github.com/carbon-design-system/carbon/issues) for duplicate problems

### Package @carbon/react ### Browser Chrome ### Operating System MacOS ### Package version https://react.carbondesignsystem.com/?path=/story/components-fileuploader--file-uploader ### React version https://react.carbondesignsystem.com/?path=/story/components-fileuploader--file-uploader ### Automated testing tool and ruleset inspect and manual testing ### Assistive technology _No response_ ### Description Issue identified during the recent Carbon Accessibility Guild call. The text preceding the Add file button lacks meaningful structure. The description (2 in above image) ("Max file size is 500kb...") that comes underneath the Upload files heading should be associated with the Add file button (3 in above image) using aria-describedby ![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/14298245/162796606-df67cae7-b673-498a-941c-9c35062ae919.png) `

items.title: [a11y]:  File uploader error message not announced or exposed on button focus
items.body:
### Package

@carbon/react

### Browser

Chrome

### Operating System

_No response_

### Package version

https://react.carbondesignsystem.com/?path=/story/components-fileuploader--file-uploader

### React version

_No response_

### Automated testing tool and ruleset

n/a

### Assistive technology

JAWS

### Description

When a user uploads too large a file, a message "File size exceeds limit" is displayed, along with a warning symbol. If this implementation is going to be accessible the message:
1. needs to be exposed when it appears
2. needs to be announced when focus lands on the associated delete button.

![image](https://media.github.ibm.com/user/1900/files/5a478b00-b3ea-11ec-9ae1-8be5e814a454)

Problems captured in [ issues with JAWS in video](https://ibm.box.com/s/9g8i7u4jyosqhdpjz2mhn2fwkrkxdxzy). 

I'll mention that I suspect this 'file' is not even equivalent to the regular file that appears after uploading (since the file has not uploaded, right). It is probably better to just expose this error message as a modal. It would never appear in the list because it wasn't uploaded. That would involve design, but is the recommended approach.

Barring that, putting both the error and  the message into an alert region and making it an aria-describedby of the delete button would accomplish it, I think.
>File size exceeds limit
500kb max file size. Select a new file and try again.
 


### WCAG 2.1 Violation

[WCAG 3.3.1 Error Identification](https://www.w3.org/TR/UNDERSTANDING-WCAG20/minimize-error-identified.html), etc.

### CodeSandbox example

https://react.carbondesignsystem.com/?path=/story/components-fileuploader--drag-and-drop-upload-container-example-application

### Steps to reproduce


To replicate
1. Start JAWS
2. choose a file that is larger than 500kb for upload. The focus seems to move to the new file and it will be outlined in red. However, focus is not actually there, and the text will not be announced
3. Tab to the 'file' in error. The text will not be announced.

items.title: File uploader: Enhanced UX for single file upload
items.body: _Use this template if you want to request a new feature, or a change to an existing feature._ ### Summary _Please describe your request in one or two sentences._ The current file uploader UX appears to be optimized for uploading multiple files - we would like to improve the UX for uploading a **single file**. Existing experience: ...having the provided-file displayed as a separate element below the drop target is sub-optimal when the drop target is embedded in form with other elements (such as a URL field for importing from a remote system, name and description fields). A current workaround is to replace the drop target with the provided file element, however if the drop target changes into a different component when the file is added, it might feel like the file has been 'processed' in some way, when actually nothing happens to the file until the user clicks the primary button (e.g 'Import'). _Clarify if you are asking for design, development, or both design and development._ Needs visual design to update the following to Carbon X, and development. ### Justification _Provide the business reasons for this request._ We would like to improve the UX for uploading a single file, and avoid unnecessary work-arounds. ### Desired UX and success metrics _Describe the full user experience for this feature. Also define the metrics by which we can measure success/failure for the user._ We think it would be good to consider an option where a single file appears in the existing boundary of the drop target, like we have today in IBM App Connect: Advantages: - the provided file appears where the user expects (where they dropped it / clicked to provide it). - no additional screen real estate is required to represent the provided file. - other surrounding elements are not displaced by the provided file element. ### "Must have" functionality _Highlight any "must have" needs and functionality for the request._ _This should not be a full list of functionality; the Carbon team will work with you to define functionality based on the desired UX._ ### Specific timeline issues / requests _Do you want this work within a specific time period? Is it related to an upcoming release?_ _NB: The Carbon team will try to work with your timeline, but it's not guaranteed. The earlier you make a request in advance of a desired delivery date, the better!_ ### Available extra resources _What resources do you have to assist this effort?_ We have raised this enhancement request internally in IBM here: https://github.ibm.com/CDAI-design/pal/issues/281 Here is the relevant part of the IBM internal github enhancement request in case you don't have access: We would like to propose the following behavior for single file import. The following screenshots are of the existing behavior in App Connect which hasn't yet been migrated to the new pattern (much of App Connect already has has been, with workarounds to address the limitations of the current pattern). As you can see below, the single file that has been provided for upload is shown in the context of the drop target, with the option to clear it. This works well in a scenario like the one shown in the example because the user also has the option to provide a URL for the file (which then disables the drop target)... _Carbon is a collaborative system. We encourage teams to build components and submit them for integration as either add-ons or core components._
